Award.AwardTitle: LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate at UMBC (2015-2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders. The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion. For the U.S. to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy. BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2014-2018 Strategic Plan, namely to "integrate education and research to support development of a diverse STEM workforce with cutting-edge capabilities." The University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC), lead institution of PROMISE: MD's Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) and the University System of Maryland (USM) LSAMP, will be the host site for the 2015-2017 USM BD Program. The activities of UMBC's program provide BD Fellows with a positive doctoral experience that includes meaningful initiatives such as professional leadership, community networking, and improved discipline-specific group and individual mentoring that have demonstrated positive impact on retention and successful graduation. Therefore, the efforts at UMBC will continue to contribute to increasing the diversity and representation in academia and the STEM workforce, thereby increasing the nation's competitiveness.

The proposed training for the 2015-2017 cohort of BD Fellows is extensive. The academic departments at UMBC have enthusiastically embraced the BD Program and are true partners in the success of the BD Fellows who will be heavily mentored to ensure they receive strong academic and professional preparation. UMBC's BD Fellows are provided excellent training in core competencies in their disciplines. The BD Fellows will also have the opportunity, early in their academic careers, to conduct cutting-edge research with top research scientists on campus and at national laboratories located in close proximity to UMBC. The proposed activities such as the required university-wide and state-wide research presentations, and training for participation in national and international research efforts, provide the BD Fellows with creative ways to enhance their preparation for STEM careers. Furthermore, the planned training in leadership, teaching, and mentoring will position the fellows well for future faculty positions, or other areas of the STEM workforce. The team has worked cohesively to facilitate the success of BD Fellows since 2005 and Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) students since 2003. Since the first BD cohort matriculated at UMBC in 2005, 108 BD Fellows have enrolled in STEM graduate programs at UMBC and at the University of Maryland, College Park. USM BD Fellows have earned 9 STEM Ph.Ds. and 47 master's degrees; 63 Fellows are currently persisting in an MS or Ph.D. program (17 students in master's programs and 46 students in doctoral programs).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation Bridge to the Doctorate Program (LSAMP BD) at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC) served 12 students in the 2015-2017 cohort. The Fellows, their disciplines, and their status are as follows:

1.   Marilyn Allen, Chemical, Biochemical, & Environmental Engineering

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD Candidate in Chemical, Biochemical, & Environmental Engineering at UMBC

2.   JeanPaul Badjo, Electrical Engineering

Status - PhD student in Electrical Engineering at UMBC

3.   Brianda Beverly, Biological Sciences

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD student in Molecular Biology at University of Maryland-Baltimore

4.   Kiante Brantley, Computer Science

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD student in computer science at University of Maryland College Park

5.   Kevin Chang, Mechanical Engineering

Status - Completed MS Degree, Employed at Meso Scale Discovery

6.   Erica Dasi, Biological Sciences

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD student in Environmental Engineering at University of South Florida

7.   BreAsia Deal, Mathematics

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD student in Mathematics at University of Maryland Eastern Shore

8.   Maraki Negesse, Biological Sciences

Status - PhD student in biological sciences at UMBC

9.   Ikenna Okafor, Biological Sciences

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD candidate in Cell, Molecular, and Developmental Biology and Biophysics at Johns Hopkins University

10.  Canessa Swanson, Biochemistry

Status - PhD student in biochemistry at UMBC

11.  Valencia Watson, Chemical and Biochemical Engineering

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD student in biomedical engineering at Georgia Institute of Technology

12.  Ashley Wayne, Mechanical Engineering

Status - Completed MS Degree, PhD student in mechanical engineering at UMBC

The fellows in the UMBC LSAMP BD Program participated in a strong program of professional development that was managed by The Graduate School at UMBC. In addition, each student was mentored by their department's faculty-level "Graduate Program Director," and a research advisor. The professional development program included topics such as: 

  • Financial Literacy
  • Dissertation Completion
  • Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR), and review of research compliance standards modules
  •  Discussions about the intersections of STEM and social justice
  • New tools for teaching
  • Working with students who have disabiities
  • Career-Life Balance
  • Career Pathways within academic institutions, govenment, non-profit, entrepreneurial, and corporate sectors
  • Leadership and Collective Responsibility
  • Applying for graduate funding, with a particulate emphasis on the National science Foundation's Graduate Research Fellowship
  • Graduate level writing and publishing
  • Developing a syllabus
  • Public speaking and preparation for research dissemination

This project had strong intellectual merit as the BD Fellow's research has been published in journals, and presented at international, national, and local conferences.  Some of the conferences include the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), American Chemical Society, Latin American and Caribbean Consortium of Engineering Institutions (LACCEI). The BDs in this cohort also took on multi-disciplinary projects that brought together social sciences and engineering, or education and information technology. 

The broader impacts of this project were that the BD Fellows were being trained in advances of science and technology. As they further develop their expertise, they will be able to contribute to a diverse STEM workforce which has a strong need for people with advanced skills. 

 

Publications Produced as a Result of this Research

R. G. Tull, S. Jangha, T. Bell, Y. Medina, and R. Parker. Sharing Peace Engineering with US based Minority Students, through the UN?s Sustainable Development Goals, in Peru. 2018 World Engineering Education Forum (WEEF).

 

White, C. K. and Tull, R. G. and Zastavker, Y. V. and Sigamoney, R.. "International Perspectives on Intersecting Engineering's Grand Challenges and the UN's Sustainable Development Goals," ASEE Annual Conference proceedings, 2018. 

 

Tull, R. G. and Hester, S. and Medina, Y. and Williams, D. N. and Medina, H. and Aparaka, E. T.. "Developing Humanitarian Engineering Perspectives Among Underrepresented Scholars Through Engagement with the Sustainable Development Goals in Global Contexts," ASEE Annual Conference proceedings, 2018.

 

R. G. Tull, High-Impact Educational Practices for Graduate Student Success (Abstract only), Understanding Interventions Conference, March 2018.

 

R. G. Tull. Championing PROMISE: A Focused Discussion on Fostering and Empowering Program Champions in STEM Doctoral Education. Proc. of the Council of Graduate Schools Alliance for Graduate Ed. & the Professoriate (AGEP) National Forum. 2017.
